page.title: 02LANDSCAPE
page.content: LANDSCAPE AROUND STAUNTON ON WYE Much of the area lies within the Garnons Estate and continuity of ownership for over 200 years has helped to create a beautiful unspoilt agricultural landscape. Garnons itself, built in about 1800 partly demolished in 1957 is still a beautiful and imposing house. The park was landscaped by Repton and still contains many fine oak trees. The area is noted for its hardwood timber, and trees and well-kept hedges still abound. In 1985 Sir John Cotterell gave an oak tree from the estate for the rebuilding of York Minster after the fire there. Staunton has a network of footpaths, the remnant of early village trackways. It lies on a hill with fine views all round. Probably the best is from the church over the river Wye to the Black Mountains.
